intro: Gilia spergulifolia, commonly known as the desert gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its slender, branching stems and showy, clustered flowers. The plant typically blooms in late spring to early summer, producing bright pink or red flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in sandy or rocky soils. Gilia spergulifolia is adapted to withstand drought conditions and is often found in desert scrub and grassland habitats.
